introduction.p: Just as area or measure might be used to describe the size of certain subsets of Euclidean spaces in geometry or analysis, topologists also have notions of size. But since stretching should not affect the topological properties of a space, topological size instead considers the cardinality of certain types of subsets of the space or its topology.

definition.p: A set is said to be finite if there exists an injection from that set to the set \setList{0,1,\dots,n-1} for some n\in\mathbb N. A set is infinite if it is not finite.
A set is said to be countable if there exists an injection from that set to the set \mb N. A set is uncountable if it is not countable.

proposition.p: A set S is infinite if and only if there exists a surjection from S to \mb N.
A set S is infinite and countable if and only if there exists a bijection from S to \mb N.
